awd_titl_txt: RPA-Directed Repair of DNA Damage in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
When plant cells are challenged with DNA damage induced by environmental radiation or by pathogen infection, Replication Protein A (RPA) is a first responder in the cellular decision-making processes that promote cell survival and help maintain the integrity of the genome. Plants contain multiple RPA proteins, and these are thought to have specialized functions that allow the plant to respond to different sources of DNA damage. To address this idea, this project employs a multi-faceted approach, exploiting the genetic power of the model plant Arabidopsis and leveraging biochemical and protein chemistry methods. The results will illuminate a novel response in plants to the DNA damage from various assaults, including pathogen infection. The long-term outcome of the work could lead to development of plants with heightened disease resistance.  Educational goals include providing research training for undergraduate and graduate students and involving at-risk high school students in hands-on research. Students at all levels will engage in communicating scientific information to lay audiences, simultaneously enhancing their own learning and improving public appreciation of science. 

The project objectives are to discover cellular mechanisms for repairing DNA double-strand breaks. DNA breaks can be induced by abiotic sources, such as UV or ionizing radiation, or by biotic sources, such as pathogen infection.  This research will explore the role of the important DNA-repair factor, RPA, which is hypothesized to be a key regulator of the cellular decisions involved in properly repairing DNA breaks in response to both abiotic and biotic sources. The main experimental objectives are to: 1) generate a model for RPA-dependent repair by examining how RPA responds to DNA breaks induced by radiation sources; 2) determine if RPA is required for repair of pathogen-induced DNA double-strand breaks, and 3) determine biochemical interactions and modifications of RPA in response to DNA damage. These data will be integrated into a holistic model of RPA functions to inform future functional analysis of cellular DNA repair in this and other systems.  The results have the potential to improve crop production in response to abiotic and biotic threats.

por.por_cntn:
DNA damage is of consequence to all living organisms. Damage if left unrepaired leads to genomic mutation and chromosomal loss, resulting in cell death or disease. In plants, regulation of responses to DNA damage is of particular importance since plants are constantly exposed to harmful environmental factors (abiotic stress) including constant exposure to UV light, soil contaminants including heavy metals, and radon.  Moreover, plant pathogens directly induce DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in plant tissues, the most toxic and detrimental form of DNA damage. This proposal aims to identify plant cellular mechanisms that respond to, and repair, DNA damage. Specifically, we employ here the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana as a powerful genetic system to study the role of the single-stranded DNA binding protein Replication Protein A (RPA) in activating cellular responses to DNA damage (including DSBs) in response to pathogens. We hypothesize that RPA plays a critical, upstream role in the cellular decisions of how and when DSBs are repaired, including DSBs induced by pathogen infection. To test this hypothesis, we employ genetic approaches to determine the role of individual RPA members in repair of double-strand breaks, induced both endogenously (genetic repair assay) and through pathogen infection. Our current results show differences that can be attributed to unique roles in processing of DNA double-strand breaks. To futher define these unique differences, we employ CRISPR technolgies to delete critical portions of RPA memebers to further characterize the individual roles in repair.

Overall, understanding how these pathways work will allow us to better understand how plants integrate the massive amount of DNA damage threat from their environment with plant development, and potentially provide new strategies for biotic and abiotic stress mitigation in crop species. These strategies could ultimately provide increases in crop yields, and reductions in chemically applied pesticides.  In addition, this project will provide opportunities for high school students, undergraduate, and graduate students to begin research projects in the lab, and help them learn about the integration of molecular techniques with advances in agriculture.
